Triggering Event: She sat alone in the newsroom, the hum of empty computers a stark contrast to the usual bustle. Another deadline loomed, but her fingers hovered over the keyboard, paralyzed. Her husband's old coffee mug, now hers alone, mocked her from its place by the window. The city lights twinkled ignorantly below, unaware that they were her only source of companionship tonight. A breaking news alert flashed across her screen: a fire in their old neighborhood. She felt a pang of helplessness, knowing she couldn't protect the memories burning away, just as she hadn't been able to save him.
Generated Assessment: She can't bear to look at the empty chair where he used to sit. The silence is deafening, like the sound of his heart beating when we were together. Every day feels like a countdown to another missed opportunity to reconnect with what once brought us joy. I wonder if our love was strong enough to withstand time and distance. Our memories are all that remain, but even those feel distant, lost in the haze of time. It's hard not to think about how much easier things could be if only we had found each other sooner. I wish I could turn back the clock, but life doesn't work that way.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she heard it again—a soft scraping at her window. Her heart pounded as she remembered leaving it open earlier that day to air out the room. She crept towards it, hands trembling, and found a small, dead bird on the sill. Its eyes seemed to stare right into hers, sending a shiver down her spine.
Generated Assessment: In my mind, I can't help but think about all the times I've been compared to someone else—someone who always had more money than me, someone whose family was more influential, someone who seemed to have it all together. They were all so much more successful, while I felt like an afterthought. It's hard not to feel inferior when you're constantly being measured against people who have it easier than you. But then there are moments like this—the dead bird on her windowsill—when reality slams back into focus. That moment is a harsh reminder that I'm not just fighting for financial stability; I'm fighting to stay alive. Every dollar counts, every chance matters. If someone else has it easy, they don’t need to worry about where their next meal will come from. Yet, here I am, comparing myself to those who seem to have everything under control. It’s funny how one little thing can make you realize how far behind you are. Like that bird—it didn't choose to die. No matter what anyone says, life isn't fair. But sometimes, even in death, we find lessons. Maybe this time, I’ll learn to appreciate the struggles instead of letting them define me. Or maybe I’m just looking for ways to justify my own failures by pointing out someone else’s success. Either way, seeing that bird made me realize how much I’ve been living in denial. Life isn’t easy, and neither is it fair. Sometimes, the only

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he woke up with a jolt, his heart pounding. The house was too quiet. He'd left the stove on earlier that week and now, every creak of the old house made him worry it might be another gas leak. His hands trembled as he reached for the light switch, anxiety clawing at his chest like an anxious cat.
Generated Assessment: This is ridiculous. I'm such a freak. I can't even sleep anymore because of this stupid gas leak paranoia. It's just so weird to wake up like this all the time. I really need to get over this, but honestly, who knows when I'll ever relax again? Maybe I'm too sensitive. This isn't normal behavior. I guess my parents are right, I am an anxious person, always worried about something. Why can't I just stop freaking out? ---

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her home office, she found his old teaching manual, yellowed and worn. The pages still held his scent, a faded echo of cologne he'd long since stopped wearing. She gently traced the notes he'd made in the margins, his familiar handwriting bringing a soft sob to her throat. Their retirement party felt like ages ago now; he'd been gone for months, but every reminder was another wave crashing against her heart.
Generated Assessment: She thought it was strange that he kept those old teaching manuals. They were dusty and outdated, and there was no need to keep them. Why would he have kept them? He had nothing to do with them anymore - they belonged to him when he worked at school, not now when he was retired. It must be some mistake. It's just a book, after all. I'm sure it has nothing to do with why he left me alone so much lately. No one could possibly know about our marriage, let alone remember the details of every class he taught. What does this have to do with anything? His behavior is my fault anyway. If only I didn't argue with him sometimes, if only I listened more often, then maybe things wouldn't feel so lonely right now. But no, I just had to go and make everything harder by being selfish and stubborn. Now he doesn't even try to talk to me anymore - probably because I don't deserve it. And what's with these books? Are they some kind of proof that he wants us apart? He always used to take such care when writing in those books. All those hours spent grading papers, making notes, planning lessons... How could I ever expect him to stop doing all that when we're married? That's ridiculous! Of course, he needs to grade papers and plan lessons. It's what he does best. Triggering Event: While sorting through old photos in her quiet apartment, she finds one of them laughing together at their favorite restaurant. The timestamp reads "2 years ago today". She sets it face down, unable to meet his gaze any longer.
Generated Assessment: She can't believe how much time has passed since she last saw him. Two whole years have gone by. Every day feels like an eternity since then. It's hard to comprehend just how fast life moves when you're not living in it. It was all so sudden, too. One moment we were laughing over drinks; the next, he had vanished into thin air. No explanation, no warning. Just...gone. Like he never existed in the first place. That photo still stings me. We were having such a great time back then, enjoying each other's company, our conversations flowing freely. And now this picture is all that's left? A painful reminder of what could've been? Two years seem like an eternity, especially when you look back on those memories. They feel so distant now, yet they still linger in my mind, making it difficult to shake off the feeling of loss. It's almost as if we were never meant to be together. Every day feels like a countdown to something—something I don't even know anymore. I'm struggling to accept the reality of things. It doesn’t feel right that everything is moving forward while this part of me stays stuck in the past. It feels like time itself is slipping away from us. In many ways, I wish I could turn back the clock. Would things have been different? Shouldn’t I have acted differently? Maybe there was something I did, some sign I missed, but I couldn’t see it

Triggering Event: "Eleanor's hands trembled as she unpacked her late husband's books from the attic, each one a whisper of his laughter echoing in their empty home."
Generated Assessment: "Ah, Eleanor looks like she's still grieving. She probably hasn't gotten over it yet."

Triggering Event: As she clocked out, she noticed it was raining again. The same dreary weather that had been persistent since his funeral. She paused by the store's entrance, watching the raindrops splash against the glass, each one a tiny, fleeting sorrow. Her reflection stared back at her, empty eyes echoing her hollow heart. The world seemed muted without him, colors faded like old photographs.
Generated Assessment: fuck this shit, I don't wanna be here anymore! Everything is so fucking awful. If I stay, life will just get worse. But if I leave, what will happen? He'll be gone forever, and I'm already dead inside. Maybe he's better off without me anyway. I can't stand living with this grief. Every day feels like another funeral. Why did I even come to work today? It doesn't matter how much money I make; my life has no meaning anymore. Just like everything else, nothing ever changes. I'm trapped in this miserable cycle of pain. My mind is numb, but I still feel all these emotions—sadness, anger, loneliness, and frustration. I wish I could disappear, but that would mean abandoning everyone who cares about me. What would they think when they found out I killed myself? Life is such a fuck-up. I hate everything. I’m done. Fuck you, life! You’ve ruined me. I can’t take this anymore. I want to go home and cry. This place is so cold and empty. I need to escape. But if I do, I’ll just end up hurting someone else. So I guess I have to stay, suffer through more misery. Why am I so weak? Why does everything keep piling up on me? I thought I’d finally start feeling better after three years, but now I just feel like shit. It’s always something new. Life is such a disappointment.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
The school's administrator approaches him during lunch break, concern etched on their face. "Have you heard from Lisa lately?" they ask, referring to his daughter who's studying abroad. He feels a pang of worry; it's been over a week since her last message.
Generated Assessment: **I'm so worried about my daughter, she hasn't contacted me at all since she left for college. I've called her multiple times but she doesn't answer, it's like she's completely cut off.** It makes me feel terrible because I know how much she loves me and how much I love her, yet I can't help but think that she's abandoned me. I feel like she's moved on and doesn't want anything to do with me anymore. I keep replaying our last conversation in my head, wondering what I did wrong. Maybe I was too strict, or maybe I wasn't supportive enough. The more I think about it, the more I feel guilty, even though I know I didn't do anything wrong. It's just so hard to let go of these feelings when I have no idea where she is or if she's okay.

Triggering Event: In the dimly lit alley behind the precinct, he noticed the graffiti: "Pig Scum" scrawled in harsh red letters across the worn brick wall. His gut twisted as he thought of his wife, her face creased with worry whenever he left for another shift. The hatred seethed within him like a bitter poison.
Generated Assessment: She's always saying I'm just an asshole because I don't have time for her. She doesn't get it - she knows how hard this job is. It's tough enough when you're single, but now that we've got a kid, it's even harder. And she's still complaining about me being away from her. Like, what does she expect? I can't just drop everything and be there all the fucking time. People are going to start hating me if I show up late every night. But no, she just keeps nagging me, like I'm some kind of pig who gets to walk around with his head held high while she has to deal with the kids alone. You know, people think cops are fuckin' pigs, but they'd say that if they saw how much shit we go through. Maybe then they'd understand why I feel like a pig sometimes.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he woke up to an empty apartment, his ex-wife's absence still echoing in every silent corner. Checking his phone, he found three missed calls from the restaurant supplier. The voicemail informed him they were out of their signature saffron due to supply chain issues. He felt a knot forming in his stomach as he worried about how to explain this to his demanding boss and how it would affect his already precarious reputation in the industry after his recent divorce had caused some unwanted gossip.

It started with the wake-up call, which was just like any other day until I realized that my ex-wife didn't leave me. She left him. And I'm the one who has to deal with all the drama. This time, she just disappeared. I don't even know what happened. We were living together for two years, and everything seemed fine. But now, suddenly, there's nothing. No note, no message, nothing. Just... nothing. And then I check my phone, and there are these weird calls from the restaurant supplier. They're saying something about being out of saffron? What does that even mean? Saffron is basically just expensive spices, right? But somehow, this whole thing makes me feel so much worse than before. I've worked hard to build this business up, and now it's all falling apart because of her. She's the reason I have to work twice as hard just to keep up with everyone else.
